title: 108_s742
content: The Act titled "International Disability and Victims of Warfare and Civil Strife Assistance Act of 2003" is established for the purpose of providing assistance to individuals affected by warfare and civil strife. The Act "International Disability and Victims of Warfare and Civil Strife Assistance Act of 2003" aims to assist individuals affected by warfare and civil strife. Congress acknowledges the widespread impact of landmines globally, with millions of landmines in over 60 countries causing thousands of casualties annually. Despite significant U.S. investment in mine action programs, only a small portion directly aids landmine victims, highlighting the need for more support. The Act "International Disability and Victims of Warfare and Civil Strife Assistance Act of 2003" aims to provide prosthetics and rehabilitation for landmine and war victims in developing countries, addressing accessibility, social stigmatization, and economic opportunities. Enhanced coordination among Federal agencies is needed to improve assistance programs for victims of civil strife and warfare. Disabled individuals have lower education and income levels, with higher poverty rates according to the World Bank. The Act "International Disability and Victims of Warfare and Civil Strife Assistance Act of 2003" aims to provide assistance for individuals with disabilities, including victims of landmines and civil strife. Disabled individuals are more likely to have incomes below poverty level and less likely to have savings and assets. International human rights conventions emphasize the protection of rights for individuals with disabilities through equality and non-discrimination principles. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include a new section on International Disabilities and War Victims Assistance. The President is authorized to provide assistance to individuals with disabilities, including victims of civil strife and warfare, in foreign countries. This assistance may include developing local capacity for medical and rehabilitation services, training medical professionals, and supporting sustainable prosthetic services. Support for sustainable prosthetic and orthotic services, psychological and social rehabilitation, policy reform, educational efforts, coordination of programs, and establishment of appropriate entities in foreign countries for individuals with disabilities, including victims of civil strife and warfare. Support for coordination of programs, projects, and activities related to assistance for individuals with disabilities, including victims of civil strife and warfare, through education, public awareness, training programs, and reintegration into society. Assistance prioritized through nongovernmental organizations and governments to establish norms and policies related to rehabilitation for individuals with disabilities. Funding is authorized to support programs for individuals with disabilities, including victims of civil strife and warfare, regardless of other laws. SEC. 4. RESEARCH, PREVENTION, AND ASSISTANCE FOR INTERNATIONAL DISABILITIES AND WAR VICTIMS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is authorized to conduct programs in foreign countries related to individuals with disabilities, including victims of landmines and civil strife. Grants can also be provided to NGOs for research, prevention, and public awareness programs for individuals with disabilities in foreign countries. Programs established for individuals with disabilities in foreign countries require coordination with the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development and approval from the Secretary of State. Activities may include research on trauma, rehabilitation, and medical care, focusing on victims of landmines and civil strife. Interventions to reduce post-traumatic stress and promote well-being, including developing medical response tools and instruction manuals for patients and healthcare providers. Facilitation of peer support networks for individuals with disabilities, including victims of landmines and civil strife in foreign countries. The curr_chunk discusses social rehabilitation, economic reintegration, training for peer support networks, sharing expertise from research centers for individuals with limb loss and disability in war-affected countries. The curr_chunk focuses on developing a database of best practices to address the needs of war-related disabled individuals, including access to medical care and supplies. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned for fiscal years 2003 through 2004. The curr_chunk focuses on the expertise of the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to provide advice and expertise on prosthetics, orthotics, rehabilitation, and disability assistance to other federal departments and agencies, including temporary assignment of personnel for assistance programs in foreign countries. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs can offer advice and expertise on prosthetics, orthotics, rehabilitation, and disability assistance to other federal departments and agencies. Additionally, technical assistance is provided to private voluntary organizations for planning, development, operation, and evaluation of landmine assistance, research, and prevention programs.
